dimensions: plate (sheet trimmed inside plate): 14.9 × 10 cm (5 7/8 × 3 15/16 in.)
creditline: Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888
markings: Collector's stamped in brown ink, verso lower right: A.F. von Lanna (Lugt 2773)
inscribed:
Signed in plate, center: HGoltzius [z in reverse]

Printed in margin around medallion: IOHAN GOLS VAN KEISERWERDT SEINES ALTERES 44

Printed in cartouche, lower center: Wan man als khan, außrouten und vertreiben / Moiß doch die lieb, ewig bleiben.

In graphite, verso: Dresden

makers.displaydate: 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Hendrick Goltzius, 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: In this portrait engraving, considered to be his earliest, Goltizus pays tribute to his father, Jan Goltz, who was a glass painter by trade. According to Goltzius’s biographer, when Goltz realized that his son would rather draw figures of men than letters of the alphabet, he allowed Hendrick to leave school and become his apprentice. The monkey at the bottom left bears the Goltz family coat of arms, while the German inscription stresses enduring love ("Though man may destroy and banish all, love exists eternally").
Adalbert von Lanna [1836-1909, Lugt 2773]; sale of his collection, Stuttgart, May 11-22, 1909, possibly lot 1800; Junius S. Morgan [1867-1932]; bequeathed to Princeton University Art Museum, 1932.
